values: CMCC-CM2-SR5
CMCC, CESM, climate model
No fluxes corrections are used in the model.
CMCC-CESM

In comparison to its previous version, the model contains many substantial science and infrastructure changes and improvements in all its components. These new advancements include: a different atmospheric model component (CAM) that incorporates significantly advanced features for turbulence and convection representations; a different land model component (CLM) with increase number of PFT components and updated land processes representation; a community based seaice model (CICE) with state of the art thermodyanics formulations and additioanl parameerizations; an updated ocean component (NEMO) with additional features to describe ocean interior dynamics, small scale paramterizations and improved computational capabilities.
Fortran, C, Python, Perl

The top-level, independent components are: atmosphere (CAM), land (CLM), ocean (NEMO), sea ice (CICE), river (RTM). These components are coupled to each other via a hub-and-spoke coupling architecture (CPL).
Other: CPL6/MCT
Ocean grid

The details of the model tuning will be described in the CMCC model description manuscript. The primary tuning involved the top-of-the-atmosphere (TOA) heat flux in pre-industrial control simulations. Our desire was to achive a rather small TOA (e.g. < 0.1 W m^-2), mostly working on atmospheric aerosol indiret effects and land processes related to the snow cycle in northern emisphere.
top-of-the-atmosphere (TOA) heat flux, global-mean ocean temperature, sea-ice extent, sea-ice volume, glacial mass balance, etc.
Ocean meridional overturning circulation,  sea-ice distributions, snow cover on nothern emisphere
Adjustments of aerosol indirect effect
Both the coupled system and the individual model components conserve heat.
Both the coupled system and the individual model components conserve freshwater / salt (at best of used formulations)
In the coupled configurations, surface heat fluxes are exchanged across the component models in a fully conservative way.
All flux exchanges are done in a fully conservative way.
Heat is conserved through the coupler except that the heat content of precipitating water is not tracked.
All flux exchanges are done in a fully conservative way.
All flux exchanges are done in a fully conservative way.
Stream temperature is not modeled thus there is no heat exchange between the land and the ocean.
All freshwater and salt flux exchanges are fully conserved.
All freshwater flux exchanges are fully conserved.
Fresh water is conserved through the coupler.
All freshwater flux exchanges are fully conserved.
All freshwater and salt flux exchanges are fully conserved.
A river routing scheme is used. All liquid and frozen runoff fluxes are sent to the ocean model using conservative mappings.

The salt / freshwater content of these basins are kept constant throughout a simulation using a marginal sea balancing scheme where access (deficit) freshwater is sent to (taken from) the nearest ocean point.
All salt exchanges between the ocean and sea ice models are done conservatively.
